text: Calcium signalling in T cells stimulated by a <extra_id_0> cyclophilin B <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - binding protein .
The immunosuppressant drug cyclosporin A blocks a calcium - dependent signal from the T-cell receptor ( TCR ) that normally leads to T-cell activation .
When bound to cyclophilin , cyclosporin A binds and inactivates the key signalling intermediate calcineurin .

To identify potential cellular homologues of cyclosporin A that might regulate calcium signalling , we have cloned human genes encoding <extra_id_0> cyclophilin B <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - binding - proteins using the yeast two-hybrid system .

One gene product , when overexpressed in Jurkat T cells , specifically induced transcription from the <extra_id_0> interleukin-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> enhancer , by activating the T-cell - specific transcription factors NF-AT and NF-IL2A .

text: This protein , termed <extra_id_0> calcium-signal modulating cyclophilin ligand <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> CAML <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , acts downstream of the TCR and upstream of calcineurin by causing an influx of calcium .

<extra_id_0> CAML <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> appears to be a new participant in the calcium-signal transduction pathway , implicating <extra_id_0> cyclophilin B <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in calcium signalling , even in the absence of cyclosporin .
